profileText: A Delegate from New York; born in Southold, Long Island, N.Y., August 30, 1734; was graduated from Yale College in 1754; studied law; was admitted to the bar and practiced in Southold, N.Y.; delegate to the Provincial Congress 1775-1777; member of the state assembly 1777-1783; Member of the Continental Congress 1779-1783 and 1788; served in the state senate 1784-1792 and 1794-1809; member of the state constitutional convention in 1801; clerk of Suffolk County from January 1784 to March 1810 and from March 1811 until his death; regent of the University of the State of New York 1787-1811; was a Federalist; died in Southold, N.Y., September 27, 1811; interment in the Presbyterian Cemetery.

researchRecord.name: 1774, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Ezra L'Hommedieu to Jedediah Elderkin written on June 15, 1774.

recordLocation.name: Department of Literary and Historical Manuscripts

researchRecord.name: 1789, 1 map.
researchRecord.description: A 1789 survey map by Moses DeWitt of Ezra L'Hommedieu's property at the south end of Seneca Lake, Schuyler County, New York.

researchRecord.name: 1805, 1 page.
researchRecord.description: A Republican Party of New York City broadside from April 25, 1805. The broadside is direct to the Republican Electors of the Southern District of New York, putting DeWitt Clinton and Ezra L'Hommedieu forwards as candidates for the two senate seats to be filled in the upcoming election.

researchRecord.name: In the John Tayler Papers, 1775-1829, 2.5 cubic feet.
